climbs.name: Stuffed Monkey
climbs.fa: Thomas Batey II or in this case the first, R. Suggett, J. Batey, P. Suggett, and a good Chiwiener

content.description: This balancey and thoughtful line keeps you searching for outside holds in order to prevent barn-dooring out of the thing. The movement is consistently fun all the way up. Look around for those holds and the occasional woodpecker.
content.protection: Five standard and one long QD along with runners for the chains.
content.location: Near the south end of the Upper Canopy and just left of the Donkey Kongs on an obvious face.

content.description:
Sparkle

climbs the relatively clean, bolted face just right of the thin crack start of

Donkey Kong Country

. Worthwhile for a quick warm-up. Named for the best tequila sold in the States. Happy 51.
content.protection: Six draws should do it, unless the carabiners have been ripped off.
content.location: Look for a line of tan bolt hangers. Â Equipped with keeper carabiners for a quick lower.

climbs.name: Monkey On My Back
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett, Andy Ross and Gene Vallee

content.description: Start low on the easy face to reach the first bolt.  This avoids the very loose blocks at the base of the arete and keeps everybody safer. Make sure you clip the second bolt prior to a fun filled romp up steep to over hanging good rock and a turn or two around the arete.  The moves after the second and just past the third bolt are cruxie but the pump will not let up until you reach the anchor.  This is a photogenic line for those who, unlike me, have a good camera.
content.protection: Five QDs and runners for the two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the most southerly line in the Upper Canopy and just left of Stuffed Monkey.

content.description: An exciting and aesthetic, mixed line.  Start on a steep, juggy face and climb up and right passing four bolts. Ever thinning, this route's crux lies in the middle. The climbing gets steeper as you ascend and eases up in difficulty as it gets higher. Finish the route up a fingers/thin hands crack to a chain anchor. Cool moves over great rock! A really fun line.
content.protection: Draws and slings for four bolts and small to medium cams/stoppers. Finish at a chain anchor.
content.location:
After passing the

Upper Jungle

proper, at the apex of a small slope, this is the first line you encounter.

content.description:
Similar to a son, this is a smaller less intense version of its

predecessor

.

DK Junior

is a fun line that shares the same start as

Donkey Kong

, but after the initial hand crack, break right across a spooky ledge to a left leaning crack. Follow this feature passing the final crux up to a chain anchor. Cool climbing with good protection, this makes a nice escape plan from the steeper, more cruxy

Donkey Kong

.
content.protection: A single set of cams up to six inches, a few long runners and draws.
content.location:
On the far left side of the

Upper Canopy

, this in one of the last routes on the wall.

content.description: (aka Donkey Kong Jr. Direct) Delicate moves in the thin crack and crimps out right. Protects in the thin crack. Move right and take the #4 size crack of DK Jr. to the chains. The angle of the rock keeps it from being pumpy and consistent with 9+.
content.protection:
Bottom Section: a couple small cams from 0-2 TCUs, nuts, and a black tricam wouldn't hurt either.

Top: 2 or 3 BD #4s
content.location: This route is the thin crack below the OW of DK Jr.

content.description:
A great, exciting line that follows a double set of hand cracks to an arete, then back across a ledge to the anchor. Well protected, steep and sustained, this line offers great climbing, A must do for the area.

The first ascent was reminiscent of the game

Donkey Kong

, only instead of hucking barrels, we were tossing choss blocks.
content.protection: Gear up to a #3 camalot, stoppers and slings. An extra #2 and #3 camalot or equivalent may be nice to have.
content.location:
On the far left side of the

Upper Canopy

. This line starts low in a recess and follows two, left leaning hand cracks.

climbs.name: Chimp Off the Old Chiwiener
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett, Phyllis Suggett, and Thomas Batey II

content.description: This intimidating line starts on overhanging seemingly loose blocks. Not so!  The blocks are solid!  Move through the overhanging section to steep edging on great rock.  You can make this hard on yourself and follow the bolt line or move a bit right where a few right hands can make a difference.
content.protection: Seven QDs and runners for the chains.
content.location: Just right of Stuffed Monkey (shares the same anchor) and near the southern end of the Upper Canopy.

content.description: This IS the real deal!  Sustained climbing on great rock and a beautiful location.  Did I mention the easy approach?  The start is hard and bouldery, but the finish is bold and scary!  If you want a difficult but safe challenge, then this overhanging line is your project to work.  And work you will!  It is a beta intensive route that will talk long and hard to your brain and forearms.
content.protection: Seven QDs and something for the chains.
content.location: This line is just left/south of Stuffed Monkey and follows the arete to a separate two bolt chain anchor.
